Hello Everyone,

I'm currently in Grade 12 but in about a month I'll be in College. I've only started using Lean yesterday, I barely have any experience with proof assistants, only knowing some basic Idris2 but the technology heavily interests me.

I'm currently going through the "Theorem Proving in Lean 4" book, though in my install Proof : Prop â†’ Type was not found. I know later on it's mentioned that Proof is redundant though I'd still like to know how it is defined. Als
Can you give a more precise pointer in to the book? Where is Proof discussed?

It is mentioned at the very start of Chapter 3: Propositions and Proofs as a way of introducing the Propositions-as-Types paradigm.
Proof is not actually something in Lean. This discussion of Proof was more to explain a possible way that logic could be encoded in Lean, not how it actually is. Lean actually expresses proofs without the Proof type. It explains later that if P is a proposition then instead of writing Proof P to represent the types of proofs of P, we can just consider P to be the type of its own proofs (this is the subject of the rest of the chapter).
Perigord has marked this topic as resolved.
